Fields.DialogueText: Your presence is really helping, Nellie. We've really been making headway against the Morganas.
It's nothing, Captain. The poison apple threw them off their guard, and when they got wise to that, I already had another plan waiting.
As I was saying, you're singularly impressive. If we keep up our momentum up like this, we can roll up the Morgana fleet before too much longer.
And then what?
What do you mean? After the Morganas?
Yes, what happens when we defeat the bally BF and then we're just a big lot of ships and folk from all over, in a big pile?

Fields.MenuText: If you have time to worry about the future, I can find more work for you to do in the present.
I'm sure we'll think of something, Nellie. We've all been through too much to turn on each other after all of this.
There's still a war on. Once the truce is over, we'll all still be soldiers. But I know we'll make it work.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Fair enough, Captain - we'd best not drink our tea before it boils.
That's my thought exactly - we'll take these monsters apart and fix everything, bingo bango bongo.
That's... true, Captain. Sorry to blag you for it. I'm glad you're here now, at least.
By the way, I assume you've noticed...
Oh, yes. Moving to intercept.
@BATTLE
Hey there, Nellie. I brought a brace of brown ales up from the galley - if you can enjoy a moment of peace.
Ah, ta. I was worried they'd all go missing before I had a chance to call bagsie on any of them.
It is what I'm here for. What kind of captain would I be if I didn't keep my ship properly fueled?
Blimey, don't look so chuffed about bringing a lady a drink. People will think you're up to something.
So you're saying you want me to take the booze back?
I'm just cocking about. It was very sweet of you - thank you.

Fields.MenuText: You had me going for a moment there, Nellie. You can play me pretty well.
I see how it is. I go out of my way to do a nice thing for you, and I'm met with mockery and ridicule.
You're very welcome.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, I am nothing if not a master of all tactics, conversational or otherwise.
Get used to it, Captain. And you had better be able to give as good as you get. I'm not much for coddling.
Now give me my....
*ALARM*
Oh, for the love of....
It's all right. I'll put them in the cold room by the kitchen, and we'll get them after we hit the BF.
@BATTLE
Bite your tongue.
Heh.
Nellie? Why the long face?
Ah, hello there, Captain. Just a minor flap. Nothing too serious.
Good. I need a distraction from all the paperwork. Tell.
It's a bit of family codswallop, Captain. Rodney has been working hard, and with the battles coming chock-a-block like this, I'm worried they're starting to wear her down.
Huh. We could see about rotating her for refit.
It won't work, Captain. She's always been belligerent, ever since the mutiny. If we try to take her off the line, she'll only push herself harder.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we need to try a different tactic, something that appeals to her.
What was that about a mutiny? Is she that disruptive of a ship? I couldn't imagine that from your sister.
I'm sure her crew is looking out for her. Try not to worry.

Fields.DialogueText: I have no idea what that'd be, Captain. She almost never does what I tell her, after all.
Well, she is the younger child. And it was just a little wages mutiny a few years ago, nothing that will hurt the fleet. But it is when her rebellious streak surfaced.
I can't help it - she's my sister.
*ALARM*
We'll have to table this discussion, I'm afraid.
Right you are, Captain. Let's break these monsters and we'll talk afterwards.
@BATTLE
Enjoying your downtime, Nellie? I see you're writing another letter. Is this one to Rodney again?
Actually, this one's to nowt other than the king himself! Thought I'd keep him apprised of the situation. Rodney doesn't need my mother henning.
The king? George VI, *that* king?
Not very often - I don't know him that well. He was at my christening, though, and he is still my king.
Do you write to a lot of people, or just to family and select royals?
Mostly to Rodney, but there are a few others. I'll sometimes open a brown ale and tell the king - or an old officer - how the war is going.

Fields.MenuText: That's a nice thought, Nellie. I'm sure they look forward to the letters.
That seems like a waste of time. Are you sure you aren't just giving them more to worry about?
Speaking as the poor fool who has to respond from complaints from London, if you're ever tempted to refer to your monarch as, say, a "weeping toe-rag," please don't.

Fields.DialogueText: I do hope so, Captain. And I know I always appreciate their replies when I get them.
Of course not, Captain. They have a lot on their plates as it is, and I'm simply letting them know I'm safe and sound.
Relax. His Majesty is lovely.
Well and good, Nellie - but I did want to tell you that we've got a battle coming up soon.
Thanks, Captain. I'll make sure the tees are crossed and the eyes dotted, and once the ink's dry, we'll show the BF what for.
@BATTLE
I don't really have to pay attention to any other king, Captain.
Yeah, but... I mean, do you write him regularly?
So he is. Okay.
I would say I don't use the same kind of language for both, but that would be a bald-faced lie.
Well, Nellie, thank you for a lovely evening. The company was excellent, and the food was...
Thank you right back, Captain. It's almost like I can forget, for a moment, that there's a war on for our very survival.
Good. You deserve a taste of what life will be like after the fighting stops.
Only, after we fight the Morganas, we'll be fighting the Germans. You think that'll be any more relaxing than what we're doing now?
Honestly, in my more optimistic moments, I'm hoping that the war at sea ultimately gives saner heads in Germany a chance to walk back the Polish invasion.
I wouldn't bet on it.

Fields.MenuText: Why not? If I'm disappointed in the end, fine - I'm not going to stop hoping in the meantime.
Thank you, voice of bitter experience.
I suppose there's no use worrying about the world after the war, when we haven't finished winning the war yet.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe you're right, Captain. I wouldn't mind terribly being wrong this one time, if it meant we finally had peace.
Sorry, sorry. And, I suppose you're right. We're fighting for peace here; it's just poor form to act like we can't win it.
I'm going to plan for it, Captain. I have no intention of seeing the future on my tod, so you had better make it through this kerfuffle.
*ALARM*
You are as smart as ever, Nellie. Now let's clean this up.
Can't say I mind getting to exercise off some of that food.
@BATTLE
Almost adequate?
Hardly like baked rubber at all!
The Morganas haven't done much good for the world, but they've made the League of Nations halfway relevant again. Maybe that'll help in the long run.
Captain, I think things are getting worse for Rodney. Her last letter was far vaguer than usual, and I'm having trouble raising her on the radio.
I'll see if I can get a status report from our friends on her bridge. Are you worried she's hiding something from you?
Not just from me. She's not the type that would just volunteer information that might take her out of a fight.
You're suggesting...?
I think she's skimping her maintenance time to get back into the fray faster.
She's always been one for competition, and I think she wants to make sure the fleet knows that even though I'm forging tactics, she can crack boats with the best of them.

Fields.MenuText: If she's really running herself ragged, we need to put a stop to it. She could put the whole fleet in danger if she isn't running at her best.
I'm sure she knows herself best. If she says she is ready for battle, I don't see the point in second guessing her.
I trust your judgement, Nellie. I'll do whatever you think needs doing to help set this right.

Fields.DialogueText: It won't be that bad, I hope. We might just need to force her to sit through a refit and rearm, to make sure she's taking care.
Well, I do. She's a bit of a rebel, and I don't want to sit by while she goes rebel. We need to at least check on her wellbeing.
Cheers, Captain. I'll talk to her, and perhaps a few of the maintenance boys. We might have to see her drydocked for a bit.
That's a good idea, Nellie. I always enjoy seeing your tactical mind in action.
Thanks, luv. Speaking of which...
@BATTLE
Hello, Nellie - what's that you have there? Writing another letter?
Receiving, not writing, Captain. This is post from King George himself, thanking me for remembering him and such.
He actually wrote back? I wouldn't have thought he had the time.
Ah, but I'm an excellent pen pal. Definitely worth a few hours' investment.
Well, you have me there. So, what does His Majesty write you about? The war at home?
Ah, Captain, don't be a berk. You know better than to ask a Lady about her personals, don't you?
Look, I *am* a berk, and it's clearly too late for me to change. Spill it.
Heh. He writes about all manner of things. Trying to keep my morale up, I suppose. You can read it if you like - no state secrets here.

Fields.MenuText: Who else writes you letters? I've seen your correspondence going out, but not as much coming in.
I still think writing these letters is a waste of time when you could be drilling the fleet.
I'm glad to know that your relationships with your pen pals isn't entirely one-sided.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, all manner of folk. From my Sister, to my cousins in the fleets, to the folks back home, to old crew, to barmy fools gone soppy with talk of the Belles.
Yes, and it's it just a right shame that you don't have any say in what I do with my time, hmm?
Oh, I get any number of letters, and some of them I even wish to receive. It's rather easy for barmpots to get your address when it's a ship.
I suppose that makes a certain amount of sense. Get ready for combat when you finish, though - we've got Morganas on the horizon.
Perfect! That'll give me something else to write home about.
@BATTLE
I think we have a good chance of surprising them here. The strait should keep them contained enough for us to do a fair amount of damage.
I think you're on the right track, Captain. We can bottle them up and hit them hard, and then get out before the fight turns into a slog.
My thoughts exactly. Now we just need to work on disposition of the forces.
I would like to make a suggestion, Captain, if you don't mind. It's about Rodney, obviously.
I suspected as much, and I think I know what you want to ask - but go ahead and make your formal request.
I want you to place both myself and Rodney in the spearhead, so I can observe her in action and see how she's faring.

Fields.MenuText: I'll be honest, I was expecting you to ask me to hold her back from the fight.
That's what I suspected, and it's probably a better method of getting information out of her than trying to force it.
You surprised me with that one, but your tactics are always a few steps ahead of everyone else.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not her mum, Captain, and she's a bloody strong ship. Besides, she wouldn't hold still if God himself told her.
Bleeding right it is. If she won't talk to me about her troubles, I know her guns will sing out loud if anything is wrong.
That's why I'm the best, Captain, and you're jammy to have me. Be glad I haven't seen fit to turn my mind on you yet.
I understand your meaning, Nellie. Now let's turn that tactical mind back against the Morganas.
Aye aye, Captain! Let's teach the BF a thing or two about having a row with the fleet!
@BATTLE
Captain, do you remember life before the war? Back when everything was so much simpler.
I think you might have had enough brown ale for the evening, Nellie.
No, I mean it. Everything made sense, and I was proud to show the Union Jack at every port we called at.
Now? We're fighting monsters nowt ever envisioned and sailing with a bloody great fleet from all over the bloody world. It's not anything I ever suspected I would see.

Fields.MenuText: To be fair, I never thought I'd be having this conversation with a beautiful woman who was also a ship.
Are you not proud to show the Union Jack now?
Don't worry, Nellie, we'll sort this business out soon enough, and then we'll get the world back on track.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you saying ships aren't beautiful to you? Haven't you seen my cannons?
What? No, I meant it hardly feels like that's the flag I'm flying under. Sailing under. Shut up, I've been drinking.
I can't help but believe you when you say it that way, Captain. I know we can do this together.
You've got me there, Nellie. Now let's clear up these bottles - we've got a war to win.
Aye aye, Captain! Let's give the BF what for!
@BATTLE
So, have you had time to think about what you saw in the battle? I'd like to hear your opinion on Rodney.
Right. Take a seat. I've been thinking it over, and I know she's working herself too hard. I don't want to grass on her but I think it's going too far.
She was tearing the Morgana apart out there, but she's going to crack up if she keeps on like this. I heard from some mates in engineering that her crew is working overtime.
I could see about getting her orders to step out of the line of battle for long enough for a few maintenance checks.
That'll do nowt, Captain. She's not going to listen if she thinks she can get in the fray, even if it comes from the gaffer.
Right.

Fields.MenuText: I can always have her ordered off the line. Even if she won't take a refit, we can send her to light duty for a while.
I can give her a direct order to go in for a refit and lie about why it's happening. Something about an upgrade, perhaps.
I'm open to suggestions here. I don't know your sister as well as you do, and I don't really know how to handle her.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah! She'd see through that in an instant. Thanks for trying to help, but this might be a bit of a family matter.
Hah! She'd see through that in an instant. We both keep our ears to the ground for new tech, and she'd know there wasn't something new in development.
It's all right - this is a family matter. I appreciate you trying help, but I'll come up with a good way to handle her.
*ALARM*
That's fair, as long as the fleet isn't in danger. Speaking of, there's the alarm. Let's get to it.
@BATTLE
Thanks for trying to help, but this might be a bit of a family matter.
Finished with your prayers? Mind if I come in?
Of course not, come on in. I'm just finishing up another letter.
Oh? And who is the recipient of Lady Nelson's correspondence this time? His Majesty again? Your sister?
No, this one is to you. It's to help address occasional bouts of gormlessness and help you remember the bright parts of these somewhat dim days.
Seriously, thank you. Without having read the thing, I assume this is very sweet of you.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose letters are a great method for keeping a record, aren't they? I hadn't thought of that.
Still, I'm not sure I'll need a memento. This war is etching itself into my memory with every rifle shot.
I'd just as soon forget most of what we've seen and done, however.

Fields.DialogueText: I am nothing if not a font of wisdom, Captain. You'll be sure to remember that when you look back on your bundle of post.
I want you to remember more than just the battles, Captain. We need to capture the nobility, the sacrifice, and the brilliance of the people around us.
I understand the sentiment Captain, really I do. But the BF win if we let them push the sun from our sky.
Fair enough. And, seriously, I can't wait to read it.
*ALARM*
Well, that's the alarm. It looks like you'll have to practice patience for a moment longer.
@BATTLE
My gormlessness is only occasional? You flatter me.
True. If I'm honest, I didn't think you'd figure that out.
Haaaah.
This is a nice evening, isn't it? Watching the sunset without a care in the world.
You better have a few cares. This is still your ruddy great fleet, innit?
Indulge me. It can be nice to pretend you're free of responsibility, even when you're standing on the deck of a warship.
Be fair - you haven't got much responsibility on my deck.
See, I'm not going to let this turn into a discussion I can't win.
Wise. I wasn't Dux of my class for nothing, you know.

Fields.MenuText: You're a little bit full of yourself, Nellie. Has anybody ever told you that?
Y'know, I don't mean to be indelicate, but I think I'm literally the last person on Earth who needs to be reminded of how amazingly good you are.
If you say so, beautiful. I'm just glad you're on my side. I'd hate to have to deal with you as an enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: Nobody I've ever listened to, Captain. I can't abide folks who have wrong opinions like that.
I'm just inviting you to share in the aura of all-consuming victory, Captain.
Thanks, luv. I'd hate to have to be the one to blow up a fit little package like you, Captain.
Yeah, yeah. It's a good thing for you that you're absolutely magnificent.
Am I?
@BATTLE
You, my dear, are *absolutely*...
*ALARM*
I hate those things so much.
So, Nellie, did you have a chance to talk to Rodney yet? Have you sorted out the problem?
You'd think she'd know she ought to listen to her sister, who happens to be one of the best ships in the fleet. Right?
Okay. How bad was it?
It's not like she shot at me or anything. But the stupid girl barely gave me the time of day, and I can tell she didn't take a single word to heart.
Well, how did you approach her in the letter? Do you think you insulted her?
No I didn't insult her, you pillock! She's the second best ship in the fleet - what could I possibly say to her to make her tetchy?

Fields.MenuText: I think I might be starting to see the problem. Do you normally talk to her like this?
I'm sure she's just going through a rough patch, and she'll be ready to talk on her own time.
This isn't just a family squabble, Nelson. People are risking their lives out here.

Fields.DialogueText: What are you on about, the way I talk to her? She's family, Captain. And I treat her as such.
We don't have the luxury of waiting for her to get over her sad little fit.
I know, and we can't let them down just because little Rodney feels like being a chancer.
*ALARM*
That's the alarm. We'll have to leave this for later.
That's fine, Captain. I need some time to think as it is.
@BATTLE
Have I? Ha!
I'm guessing that's a no.
Hey, Nellie - did I catch you at a good time? I just wanted to steal a few minutes.
I always have time for my favorite tea leaf, so steal away. Though I'm not sure it's worth the effort.
Oh, I don't believe that. You could be constructing grand strategies or thinking of ways to raise the spirits of the crew.
And yet, instead, I'm sitting here feeling stroppy, aren't I? So what does that say about me, then?
It says you should sit back and let your Captain enthrall and delight you.

Fields.MenuText: I brought a slice of cherry pie up from the wardroom. The cook baked it fresh.
I found a signed still from Snow White that I thought you'd like. It's the frame where she bites the poison apple.
If you truly have nothing better to do, I brought a dice cup up, in case you wanted to play a little game.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, you are far too thoughtful for my own good. I'm going to be too big for my deck plating if you keep this up.
Oh, Captain, that's perfect. I shan't ask how you got it, but you made my day! I'll hang it in my cabin, and every time I see it I'll remember ramming it down the BF's throats.
Hah! Perfect. Let's see if we can't have a bit of fun. I'm sure I can come up with something to wager.
I do my best, you know. We can't all be the fleet's most impressive battleship.
It'd be a strange world if we were. Now, come here - I think someone's earned a little...
*ALARM*
We cannot sink them painfully enough.
@BATTLE
How are you holding up, Nellie? You've seemed a bit more intense than usual lately.
Can you blame me? My own sister won't listen to a word I say. I look like a right plonker.
I understand, but you can't let Rodney's attitude get in the way of our duties to each other out here.
You don't have to tell me my duty, Captain. I'm not the one stretching herself to the limit trying to be everywhere at once.
No offense, but I think that's at least partially because I insist on bugging you at times like these.

Fields.MenuText: Would it help if I let you run a nice firing drill on your cannons? I think we can spare the ammunition.
I can have the chef whip up a nice pan haggerty and we can take some leisure time to read.
Do you think it would help you if you went and talked to the chaplain and asked for guidance?

Fields.DialogueText: I do like firing my lovely cannons... If you're sure we can spare it, I'd love to give them a good sounding.
Don't try to buy my happiness with food, Captain. Although a quiet evening with a friend and some good food does sound nice.
He won't tell me anything I don't already know, but it could be nice to talk through this with someone else.
*ALARM*
I'll have to put it on hold for a bit, though. That sounds like the alarm.
@BATTLE
Hmph.
Hey, Nellie - you're looking a little happier. Who's this letter going to?
Hey, you. This one's to King George, actually. I'd like to hear his opinion on things.
Um.
Ah. Right. I'll be the soul of discretion, Captain.
Uh-huh.

Fields.MenuText: So. What kind of advice are you expecting to hear from him?
What do you think he'll suggest you'll do about this?
Do you ask for his advice often? I figured he might be a bit busy for that.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'm not asking him for advice, exactly. But I think he genuinely wants to know what's going on, and he's got a good head on his shoulders. No harm in seeing if he has an opinion.
He can't suggest I do anything. I have full authority over my ship and crew, and none over Rodney's. But he is the King, and I trust his opinions.
I don't ask anyone for advice often. Mostly our letters are just a good way to relax, and remember there's a world out there we don't see every day.
Ah, my mistake. Well, let's hope for a speedy response, shall we?
Indeed. Let me wait for this ink to dry, and I'll swing the ship around. We have a BF to rout, after all.
So we do.
@BATTLE
What?
It's just that His Majesty has had some personal experience with a sibling one might argue had self-destructive tendencies. Tread lightly.
Well, I'll try not to make an arse of myself, anyway.
Nellie, can I get your opinion on some of these plans?
Always, Captain. I'm nothing if not willing to share my tactical acumen.
Take a look at this map - I think we can trap elements of the Morganas in this strait.
Good to see you beavering away, Captain. Yes, I think we can hit them on the side out there.
Thank you, Nellie. I always appreciate your input on tactics and strategies. And it's good to see you smiling.
Well, I do love giving the BF a good case of collywobbles.

Fields.MenuText: It's important to have a hobby that makes you smile. And I'm glad you're so easy to please.
You know what they say - do what you love, and you'll never work a day in your life.
I'm surprised they don't flee ahead of time and save themselves the trouble when they know you're coming.

Fields.DialogueText: Actually, my hobby is keeping *you* in line. Crushing the BF is more of a vocation.
A genuine pearl of wisdom. I must be rubbing off on you, Captain. Keep at it.
Well, they are a right bunch of ninnies, aren't they? It's not their fault that they aren't smart enough to about-turn at the sight of me.
Well, you're nothing if not singularly magnificent, so I'll have to take your word for it.
*ALARM*
Precisely. And there's the alarm, it looks like a few of the BF haven't gotten the message.
@BATTLE
Nelson, I need to talk to you about the last few battles.
Is there something wrong? Our tactics haven't started failing again, have they?
No, of course not. But I'm getting a little bit worried about you.
Whyever for, Captain? I'm just doing my best to hound the BF out of every squalid little bay and inlet that might offer them shelter.
That's my point, actually. Is it possible that you're so worried about Rodney running herself ragged that you're starting to do the same?
No.

Fields.MenuText: Be that as it may, I want you to watch yourself out there. You are too important to me and this fleet to be lost recklessly.
Fair enough - I'd rather see your anger vented on those monsters than anywhere else.
You aren't always this reckless, though. You damn near rammed that last Morgana.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye aye, Captain... I'm sorry Captain, I'm just bloody cross, and I'm putting it ahead of my duty. I'll try to rein it in.
That's the ticket, Captain. I'll try to be more careful, though. I don't know what you'd do without me.
Can you imagine the look on that monster's face? But I see your point. I'll be a spot more careful.
Good enough. Now, let's go show those monsters what for.
I thought you'd never ask, Captain.
@BATTLE
Nellie...
I'm just angry, Captain. I can either work it off or I can let it fester. Working it off is better.
But I promise, I'm not being stupid about it. Not least because I know you'd never let me down if I was.
Hey, look at that grin. Good news?
Actually, yes, Captain. I have a letter here you ought to see.
What happened to a lady's privacy? I thought your correspondence was sacrosanct.
Pillock. Just look at the envelope, will you? It's from His Majesty - I finally got a response to my letter.
I'm impressed. Any useful advice?
I... actually, maybe this is too personal for you to see. But, yes, I think his experiences with the Duke of Windsor gave him some insight into the Rodney matter.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you were able to hear from someone who's been in your shoes. Even if it's still a bit strange to me that it's a monarch.
That's fair.
Pillock though I may be, let me know if I can help.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, if you were as fantastic a woman as myself, then perhaps you would be permitted correspondence with the halls of the mighty.
I certainly thought so.
You're sweet, Captain. I promise, I haven't forgotten you're here.
Well. Changing the subject - if you have a few free minutes, I wonder if you might like to join me in...
*ALARM*
I think I know exactly what I'll be joining you in.
@BATTLE
Not that they're at all the same, of course.
Are you... on the verge of displaying some humility? You?
No, I'm back to calling you a pillock.
It never friggin' fails.
You wanted to see me, Nellie?
There you are, Captain. I was wondering when you'd show up. I need your help writing to Rodney.
... Okay. Do you need to borrow a pen, or...?
His Majesty pointed out that I can be somewhat... imperious. And it would behoove me to talk to Rodney as an equal.
And you could use a sounding board? Done.
All right, so I need you to read over this letter, and tell me which parts make it sound like I think she's lesser than me.
Absolutely, Nellie. Give it here and I'll be happy to read over it for you.

Fields.MenuText: This part, where you mention that anyone with good sense could see she's working far too hard and is likely to give out, should be reworded.
I think it might help if you don't refer to her responsibilities as "Those of His Majesty's second most powerful battleship."
Perhaps you should take out the bit where you explain that the only reason you're being so considerate is because King George told you to.

Fields.DialogueText: Good catch, let me rewrite that to talk about how I'm proud of her for working so hard but I'm also worried.
Oooh, good catch. Perhaps if I just call her my sister, or a ship in this fleet.
That's a fair point. I'd rather this came a bit more from my heart, and didn't sound like an imposition.
Thank you for your help, Captain. I know this will go over well with her.
I'm happy to help. Now get ready - we have a battle on the horizon.
@BATTLE
No, you berk. I want your opinion.
Luckily, I have plenty of those. So what's happening?
Nellie, where were you? We have a Morgana fleet on the horizon.
My apologies, Captain. I was with the chaplain, praying for the swift resolution of this war - among other things.
Among other things? You aren't normally this cryptic about things that aren't film screenings.
All right, Captain. It pains me to say it, but I was praying for patience for myself and my sister. We both need it, for very different reasons.
Understood. Did talking to the chaplain help you?
Quite. I appreciated the gab with him. I had no idea how ropey I'd let things become with Rodney, and it feels good to be working on it.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'm glad you're taking steps to rectify the situation. And I'm sure Rodney will appreciate it too.
I think you might find better results if you take action, rather than just praying.
As long as this gets sorted out and the fleet no longer has to worry about these disruptions, I will be happy.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope so. But it's not my place to make her thankful for my actions. I just need to respect her, and let her know I love her.
I am, you ruddy great pillock. But while I give her some space and let her think things over, praying will help me wait patiently.
Shut it, luv. I know you worry about me, whatever you might be thinking, and you're happy I'm not making a pig's ear out of this anymore.
Well, it sounds like things are getting better for you. So get yourself running and get ready for the fight.
Aye aye. Captain!
@BATTLE
Captain, come in here with me for a minute. I've got a hot pan haggerty and some brown ales tucked away.
What's the occasion?
Nothing special, Captain. I just needed a small moment of... stability, I suppose.
And you figure I make things seem stable by comparison?
Exactly. I knew you'd be the one for the job, Captain. Care for a bit of a flutter?
Did you just challenge me to a game of chance? What's the game?
Crown and Anchor. What're the stakes?

Fields.MenuText: The rest of the pan haggerty, and the loser's drink rations for the week.
Loser has to wear a silly hat tomorrow and not acknowledge it no matter what anyone says.
Loser has to write the winner a letter formally declaring them their tactical superior.

Fields.DialogueText: Blimey, you're a mean one. I suppose I'll have to take you down hard.
It can't be any sillier than the ones I've already seen you wear, Captain.
Hah, I can't have that, I already know you're not anywhere near my level.
All right, you're on. The loser can take out their frustrations on the BF.
@BATTLE
Captain, do you have a moment? I've got good news!
About Rodney?
Dead on, luv! She's actually written me a proper letter!
Oh, what does she have to say? Anything about her state of mind?
Of course not - why would she write about that? This is all about her crew and about some of her better battles.
And this is the positive result you were hoping for? Because it still sounds like she's hiding things.
We're sisters, luv - we read between the lines. But I'll wager big that you'll see her submitting for refits soon, and not pushing herself as hard.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think it's because you started treating her as an equal, and maybe she was feeling put down?
Do you think she doesn't feel like she's laboring in your shadow any longer? I can see why she was striking out on her own if so.
Not that I don't trust your intuition, but are you sure it is a change, and not just her deciding to write a bit more than usual?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps. I hadn't ever really thought about how inferior—I mean other—ships might feel in my presence. I'm working on that.
Well, it did always seem like I received more acclaim. I wonder how much of that I earned, and how much I simply gathered by being first.
Trust me, Captain. I spotted the problem, I know when it's solved. Anyroad, you'll see soon enough.
It's certainly something to think about. Anyhow, we're steaming towards the Morganas, so prepare yourself for battle.
I'm looking forward to heaping the BF in the rubbish pile, Captain!
@BATTLE
Nellie, you said you had a request? We'll be engaging the Morgana in a few minutes.
Captain, I need you to see to it that myself and Rodney are in the vanguard for this fray.
Nellie, the battle lines are set, I can't just change the order of battle on a whim, regardless of who asks.
Come on, luv, Rodney and I need this. See to it that we hit the BF first, and we'll rip those witches apart.
I would have to restructure the whole fleet and most of the fleet elements and that will take... You already have a tactical plan drawn up, don't you?
You know me so well, Captain. Here's the details. See to it, and I promise you burning hulks as far as the eye can see.

Fields.MenuText: You owe me one for this. The other fleet officers are not going to be happy about these last minute changes.
Anything for you, Nellie. But you owe me a drink and a kiss for this, as long as I'm being manipulated.
My eyes can see pretty far, Nellie. But if I get results, I'll say no more about this little change up.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, luv, whatever you want. I know how to bribe a commanding officer, after all.
You drive a hard bargain, Captain, but I think I can swing that, if you'll throw in with my mad scheme.
Cor, you're a treat, Captain. I'll let you get the fleet ready, I need to swing the guns about and get the men loading.
You get on that, Nelson. I'll go inform the fleet. Battlestations, now.
@BATTLE
Well, luv, you can't deny that that worked. We sent those monsters to Davy Jones, at least for the time being.
I don't mean to trivialize all the horror... but it *is* a pleasure to watch you work.
You say the sweetest things, Captain. I know with you in command, I'll lead us to victory soon enough.
I thought you were working on humility, Nellie. That was almost hurtful.
Hush you, you aren't keeping me around to molly-coddle you. At least, one hopes not.
True enough. It's almost like I'm keeping you around because you're an intelligent, beautiful, compassionate woman–
–Who happens to mount nine sixteen-inch guns. I know what you love, Captain.
You're not wrong, Nelson. I don't know what I'd do without you.

Fields.MenuText: You're my rock. I can't wait for this war to end, so we can see what else the future holds for us.
Without your constant belittling, I might be in danger of getting a high opinion of myself.
If it wasn't for your tactics, I wouldn't still have to listen to your self aggrandizement.

Fields.DialogueText: And you're my anchor, dragging me down into the depths of contemplation. Now stop being soppy, we're going to win this war, and then see what other surprises life holds for us.
It's my greatest calling in life. Though a high opinion isn't so bad, I just reckon it needs to stay below mine. I suppose I'll have to keep you around for that very reason.
See? What wonderful things I do for you, you ungrateful git. I have to keep you alive until you're properly appreciative, so you better get used to it.
Besides, you already get on well with my family. Cor, I think I will keep you.
